DIV1.P: AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET, in the Strand; Bookseller to Their Royal Highnesses the Prince of WALES and Bishop of OSNABURGH.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE greater part of this Masque is borrowed, with some variation, from BEN JONSON. The same liberty has been taken with a few passages of SHAKE∣SPEARE, and a Chorus of the late GILBERT WEST, Esq. The final Chorus is from DRYDEN.

The Editor humbly submits the whole to the Publick; hoping that it will not appear unworthy of the occasion to which it is adapted; and that they will receive with their usual candour this effort to entertain them by the combined powers of the most eminent pro∣ficients in the Arts of Musick, Painting, and Poetry.

DIV1.HEAD: CHARACTERS.

LIST.LABEL: SILENUS,
FIRST SATYR,
SECOND SATYR and ECHO,
THIRD SATYR,
FOURTH SATYR,
FIFTH SATYR,
SYLVAN,
PRINCIPAL FAIRIES,
LIST.ITEM: TWO CHILDREN, being their first Appearance on any Stage.
LIST.LABEL: NYMPHS,

DIV1.P: Dance of NYMPHS and SATYRS, by Messrs. FISHAR, ALDRIDGE, Mad. MANESIERE, &c. &c.
The Music composed by Dr. ARNE.
The Scenes painted by Messrs. CIPRIANI. DALL, and RICHARDS.

DIV2.HEAD: PART I.
DIV2.STAGE: A wild country; the whole Scene dark, 'till at one corner, the Moon rising, a Satyr is seen (by her light) to come forth and call.

SP.SPEAKER: FIRST SATYR.

LG.L: CHROMIS, MNASIL! none appear?
See you not who riseth here?
You were carousing late, I fear:
I'll prove if this can reach your ear.

SP.STAGE: [He winds his Cornet, and thinks himself answer'd, but is deceiv'd by the Echo.]

LG.L: O, you wake, then: come away;
Times be short, are made for play!
The hum'rous Moon too will not stay.
What doth make you thus delay?
Hath the tankard touch'd your brain?
Sure, they're fall'n asleep again!
Or I doubt it was the vain
Echo, did me entertain.
Prove again. [Winds a second time]
I thought 'twas she.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR.

LG.L: Idle Nymph, I pray thee be
Modest, and not follow me;
I not love myself, nor thee.

DIV3.STAGE: [Winds the third time, and is answer'd by another Satyr.]

DIV3.HEAD: RECITATIVE.

LG.L: Ay, this sound I better know:
Wou'd their faces they might shew!

DIV3.STAGE: [At this, other Satyrs come forth severally, and amongst them a Silenus.

LG.L: Thank us, and we shall do so.
Ay, our number soon will grow.
See Silenus!
Cercops too!
Yes; what is there now to do?
Are there any Nymphs to woo?
If there be, let me have two.
Chaster language! These are nights
Solemn to the shining rites
Of the Fairy Prince, and Knights;
While the Moon their orgies lights.
Will they come abroad, anon?
Shall we see Young OBERON?
Is he such a princely one
As you spake him long agone?
Satyrs, he doth fill with grace
Every season, every place;
Beauty dwells but in his face:
He's the height of all our race!
Our Pan's father, God of tongue,
Bacchus, though he still be young,
Phoebus, when he crowned sung,
Nor Mars, when first his armour rung,
Might with him be nam'd that day:
Lovelier than the Spring in May.
O! that he would come away!
Farewel, Bacchus! we will serve
Young OBERON.
And he'll deserve
All you can, and more, my Boys.
Will he give us pretty toys,
To beguile the girls withal?
And to make 'em quickly fall!
Peace, my Wantons! he will do
More than you can aim unto.
Will he gild our cloven feet?
Strew our heads with powders sweet?
Bind our crooked legs in hoops,
Made of shells, with silver loops?
Tie about our tawny wrists
Bracelets of the Fairy twists?
And, to spite the coy Nymphs scorns,
Hang upon our stubbed horns
Garlands, ribbands, and fine posies;
Fresh as when the Flower discloses?
And to answer all things else,
Trap our shaggy thighs with bells;
That as we do strike a time,
In our dance, shall make a chime,
Louder than the rattling pipes
Of the Wood-Gods;
Or the stripes
Of the timbrel; when we carry
Bacchus up, his pomp to vary.
O, that he so long doth tarry!

DIV3.HEAD: RECITATIVE.

LG.L: Peace! the Rock will quickly ope:
Soon you shall enjoy your hope.

DIV3.STAGE: [Rock opens, and discovers the West Front of St. George's Chapel, at Windsor, with brilliant decorations; before the Gates two Sylvans, armed with their Clubs, and drest in leaves, asleep. At this the Satyrs wondering, Silenus proceeds.

LG.L: Mark, my Satyrs, what a show!
Look! does not this Temple glow
Like another sky of lights?
Yonder sit the crested Knights,
Once the noblest of the earth,
Quicken'd by a second birth;
Who, for Prowess, and for Truth,
There are crown'd with lasting youth;
And now hold, by Fate's command,
Seats of Bliss in Fairy Land.
But their Guards! strange watch they keep!
Rouze 'em, Satyrs, from their sleep!
Holla, Sylvans! Sure they're caves
Which Sleep inhabits—
Else they're graves.
Shall we cramp 'em?
Satyrs, no.
Would we had Boreas here, to blow!
Shall we steal away their beards—
For Pan's Goat, that leads the Herds?
Let's try, whether is more dead,
One Sylvan's Club—or t'other's head.
Let us to some river take them;
Plump—and see if that will wake them.
Let them down the Hill be roll'd!
Wags, no more! you grow too bold.
There's no motion yet appears.
Strike a charm into their ears.

DIV3.HEAD: CATCH, BY THE SATYRS.

LG.L: Buz, quoth the blue flie,
Hum, quoth the bee:
Buz and hum they cry,
And so do we.
In his ear, in his nose,
Thus do you see?
He eat the Dormouse,
Else it was he!

DIV3.STAGE: [The two Sylvans start up amazed, and betake themselves to their Arms.

LG.L: How now, Sylvans! can you wake?
I commend the care you take.
Who is yonder up aloof?
Be your eyes as yet moon-proof?
Satyrs, leave your petulance,
And go frisk about, and dance;
Or else rail upon the Moon;
Your expectance is too soon.
For before the second cock,
Know, the gates will not unlock.
Say you so? Then let us fall
To a Song, or to a brawl!
Shall we, Grandsire? Let us sport,
And make expectation short.
Do, my Wantons, what you please;
I'll lie down, and take mine ease.
Brothers, sing then, and upbraid
(As we use) yond' seeming maid.—
But hold! The Woodland Nymphs, my Boys,
Appear, and promise greater joys!
Sylvans, Fauns, and Satyrs rude,
Pan's Train, and all that multitude,
Now dance in wilder rounds about,
And cleave the air with many a shout!
See, see, O see, who here is come a-maying;
The master of the Ocean
With his darling Orian:
Why left we our playing?
To gaze, to gaze,
On them that all amaze,
Whose like were never seen.
Up, Nightingale, and sing
Jug, jug, jug, jug, &c.
Raise, Lark, thy note and wing;
All birds their Musick bring;
Sweet Robin, Linnet, Thrush,
Record from every bush
The welcome of the King,
The King and Queen!

DIV3.HEAD: RECITATIVE.

SP.SPEAKER: SECOND NYMPH.

LG.L: Now, now, prepare to set;
And when your hands are met,
Begin with nimble feet
The happy ground to beat.

SP.STAGE: [A Dance till they are interrupted by Silenus.

LG.L: Stay! the chearful Chanticleer
Tells you that the time is near;
See, the Gates already spread!
Nymphs and Satyrs, bow the head!
See St. George's Fane! where now
Lives Knighthood with a crowned brow.

DIV3.STAGE: Scene opens, and discovers a Vision of the in∣side of St. George's Chapel, at Windsor, with the original Knights in their several Stalls.

LG.L: Hail, fair Knighthood; let our Lays
Vindicate thy antient Praise!
Thou too, Windsor, shalt be sung;
Mansion of Princes, haunt of Gods,
Who shall quit their bright abodes,
To view thy walls with trophies hung;
Walls by Arthur first renown'd,
Seat of Chivalry and Fame!
By Edward with new Honours crown'd;
His BIRTH, his GARTER, and his NAME.
Let our shews be new as strange,
Ever hastening to their change;
Let them oft and sweetly vary,
That beholders may not tarry!
Long to wait the pleasing sight,
Takes away from the delight.
Let us play, and dance, and sing!
Let us frolick, let us sport,
Turning the delights of Spring
To the graces of a Court.
From air, from cloud, from dreams and toys,
To sounds, to sense, to love, and joys!

DIV3.HEAD: DUET AND CHORUS.

LG.L: Whilst all the air shall ring,
And every trembling string,
With every varied voice,
In union sweet rejoice,
To sound and sing,
LONG LIVE THE KING!

DIV3.TRAILER: Curtain drops, and closes the First Part.

DIV2.HEAD: PART II.
DIV2.STAGE: The Lower Court of Windsor Castle, with a View of the Round Tower, the outside of St. George's Chapel, &c.

LG.L: WELL were the solemn rites begun;
And tho' but lighted by the Moon,
They shew'd as rich as if the Sun
Had made the Night his Noon.
Wonder none they were so bright!
The Moon then borrow'd from a greater light.
Then, Princely OBERON,
Go on!
Such is not every Night.
Tho' the Moon be gone to bed,
Fairies must not hide the head;
But sing, dance, and revel on,
In honour of Young OBERON.
And sweet OSNAPHIL his Brother,
Arthur hails him such another;
Edward too enjoins the rites,
To rank him with the listed Knights:
Worthy each alike to spring
From the Fairy Queen and King.
Now then, blythe Elves, in tunes express
The Sovereign and his Emperess,
While all confess the proper Heir
Assign'd to Arthur's Crowns and Chair.
Seek you Majesty to strike?
Bid the World produce their like.
Seek you Glory to amaze?
Here let Nations stand at gaze!
Seek you Wisdom to inspire?
Touch then at no other Fire!
Seek you Piety to lead?
In their footsteps only tread.
Every grace of Queen and King,
And of all, in them, we sing.
Now, Faies and Elves, your tasks about;
The Castle search within and out:
Strew good luck on every room,
Fix'd till the perpetual doom;
The several chairs of Order scour,
With juice of ev'ry precious flower;
Each fair instalment-coat, and crest,
With loyal blazon still be blest;
And ever, ever, in a ring,
Like to the Garter's circle, sing.
"In em'rald tufts the motto write,
"Of flow'rs purple, blue, and white;
"Like saphire, pearl, embroidery,
"Buckled below fair Knighthood's knee." The lines within inverted commas are omitted in the representation.
Away, disperse; the white plum'd Train
Begin their march along the plain,
In solemn Pomp from yonder Hall;
Vanish, and attend my call! [Exeunt Fairies.
Melt earth to sea, sea flow to air,
And air fly into fire,
While we in songs to Arthur's chair
Bear OBERON'S desire!

DIV3.P: THE PROCESSION TO ST. GEORGE'S CHAPEL, OF THE SOVEREIGN, KNIGHTS COMPANIONS, KNIGHTS ELECT, &c. &c. &c.

DIV2.HEAD: PART III.
DIV2.STAGE: Windsor Park, with a View of the Castle.

LG.L: NOR yet, my Faies, in this day blest,
Must you think or hope to rest.
Let the coarse and Country Fairy,
That doth haunt the hearth or dairy;
Let Ghosts, wand'ring here and there,
Shun Aurora's harbinger;
And banish'd f om the chearful light,
Hold company with black-brow'd Night!
W're Spirits of another sort,
And with the jolly, jolly day make sport.
Nay, nay,
You must not stay,
Nor be weary yet:
This is no time to cast away;
Or for Fairies to forget
Their nimble, nimble, feet.
Knotty joints, and limbs of clay
Seek for ease, or love delay.
Merrily, merrily, we should fare,
Whose being's a shadow, whose bodies are air.

DIV3.HEAD: A DANCE OF FAIRIES.
DIV3.STAGE: After the Fairies are vanish'd, the Scene changes to the inside of St. George's Hall, with the Throne, Tables, &c. as at the Installation. The Knights-Companions enter in Procession, and range themselves on the outside of their Table; they uncover and bow as the Sovereign passes. Ceremony of the Dinner, &c. with proper Musick. The whole to conclude with this

LG.L: Renown, assume thy Trumpet,
From Pole to Pole resounding
Great GEORGE's name!
Great GEORGE's name
Shall be the Theme of Fame.
Record the GARTER's Glory!
A badge for Heroes, and for Kings to bear;
For Kings to bear!
And swell th' immortal story
With Songs of Gods, and fit for Gods to hear;
For Gods to hear!
